--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> Those are very nice results, showing that a
> recurrent neural network
> can indeed be evolved to be able to memorize the
> necessary
> information.  I still wonder why it needed 44 nodes,
> but perhaps that
> does make sense given all the possibilities.

They are interesting results.  It would be interesting
to see how NEAT handles a game like Concentration. 
We've all got stuff we're working on, I suppose, but
I'll keep it in mind down the road.  

> When do
> you need Hebbian
> connections to learn as opposed to only fixed-weight
> recurrent
> connections?  It isn't clear.  

I did think the results of your paper were very
interesting.  The fixed-weight networks evolved better
performers more quickly, so the time to search for a
solution was smaller.  

But something I was curious about that I wasn't sure
from the paper was the efficiency of individual
networks.  You note how self-recurrency on the output
nodes of the fixed-weight networks leads to an
efficient way of implementing particular behavior,
while the adaptive networks the behavior is driven
more by the hidden nodes, and is more holistic in
nature.

Since the fixed-weight networks took less time to
evolve, I'm assuming that the networks also had fewer
nodes and connections than the adaptive ones.  Is this
a false assumption?  

Since it's a real-time domain, the speed with which an
individual makes decisions is important.  So the time
it takes for input signals to propagate through the
net and produce output is very important, isn't it?

> And what is the
> capacity of a
> fixed-weight recurrent network to remember
> information?

Yeah, that's a good question.  I believe Mitchell said
that he had poor results when starting out with a
6-card game.  Do you plan to take another whack at a
larger domain, Mitchell?  I'd be very interested to
see how things change as the problem scales up.

Derek
